The Vera Page Case was an unsolved murder case from the early 1930s. Vera Page was born in 1921 in
Notting Hill ,
London . On December 14 1931, Miss Page was reported missing by her parents in
London . Two days later, her raped and strangled body was found in the bushes by a house at Addison Road, about a mile from the victim's own house. The police thought she had been murdered somewhere else and then dragged into the growth alongside the road. The remains were examined by Sir
Bernard Spilsbury
. He discovered coal-dust and candle wax on the girl's body, as well as a piece of ammonia-stained finger bandage . Over a thousand people were questioned about the Vera Page case, and Percy Orlando Rush was the prime suspect. Rush was a forty year-old married man, who had often been seen lurking about the district on evenings. Furthermore, he had recently had a bandage applied to his finger and he worked with ammonia in a nearby laundry. Unremarked upon at the inquest was the fact that he had been previously found guilty of exposing himself to girls. He was never officially charged with murder, but is highly likely he was the murderer. However, no one saw him with Vera on the day of her death, though his movements were never verified. He died in 1961.
The above information can be verified by The Kensington News and Kensington Post of 1931-1932, and by the Metropolitan police file on the case held at the National Archives.
